word: We had good meetings in Portland, and a good hearing--never better anywhere. The house was well filled in the afternoon. The nominal Adventists let me in their hall to speak. The hall was literally packed. We had excellent attention. I had perfect liberty in speaking to the people. I walked one mile and back three times a day, and then visiting my sisters and cousins wore me. . . . Rest we must have. But we look forward to the time when "we'll lay our heavy burdens down, there's resting by and by."--Letter 25, 1868 , pp. 2, 3. (To "Dear Children Edson and Willie," December 2, 1868.)
